author: Movielopolis

text: I mean, they're not Castlevania difficult, but they're not easy. Or at least Link to the Past isn't easy. I still see the game over screen a decent amount of times when I replay it, while other Zelda games, I rarely do.
author: Mx Brooke Lee

text: The point: None of these games are actually difficult.
author: Dai

text:
I can see what you mean.
One game that doesn't use invincibility frames at all is Perfect Dark for the N64, you literally take damage from every single hit in that game and can be mowed down in one second if you are unlucky.
And that game is definitely challenging, the DarkSims still give me nightmares.
author: Laurelindo

text: I think it really comes down to invincibility frames. There are far too many ways to generate free invincibility frames in the later games. If they didn't give them or the maneuvers didn't exist, the games would be much more difficult.
author: BubbatheScrub

text: More effective maneuvers shouldn't really be an excuse to make a game easier, though - it should always be balanced so that even though you have more attack and defense options, the game will still be hard and compensate for it.
author: Laurelindo

text: And it is also the reason I bought a 3DS. =)

text: It depends on what you find difficult. Ocarina of Time's difficulty was always something like, "Okay so this is a boss, now I need to find a weak spot, figure out how to harm that weak spot, then find figure out the best strategy for that. Link To The Past's difficulty was normally more like "THINGS ARE FLYING AT ME FROM EVERYWHERE! SHIT!!!"

author: prince apoopoo

text: It's funny.  I actually did some tests regarding strongest enemies in the games.  In Alttp, there are several enemies capable of dealing 6 hearts of damage to a green tunic Link.  In OoT the strongest attacks are Ganon's swords, and an Iron Knuckle's axe which each deal 4 hearts of damage to an unarmoured Link.  With the strongest stuff on in Alttp, and the defence boost in OoT, the strongest attacks deal 2 hearts of damage.

author: Mitchfynde

text: @1600Percent So close to my list!  I put the original in 7th place with Link's Awakening and the Oracle titles above it.  Majora's Mask and OoT will often switch places depending on how I'm feeling.  The rest of the series was way too linear for my tastes.  I love games where you can utilize almost any trick in your arsenal to get things done in a different order without having a negative effect on 100% completion.  That's why Super Metroid and this game are infinitely replayable.
author: SMRPGFAN101

text:
This is my personal top five favorite list of Zelda games, in order!
1) ALTTP
2) Majora's Mask
3) Ocarina of Time
4) Legend of Zelda
5) Link's Awakening
author: 1600Percent

text: @Lusebusen Couldn't have said it better myself.  Ocarina of Time was good and is generally the most favored Zelda game of them all, but in my opinion it derived most of its epicness from ALTTP.  The music, the 3 dungeon/master sword/endgame dungeon layout, Kakariko Village.  Nothing compares to ALTTP, and nothing ever will.

text:
the fanfare beckons you into a new, unexpected world where everything you know is deformed, yet sickeningly still recognisable. You realise the last few hours you spent hunting down your Excalibur was nothing but training for a bigger, more daunting quest. You look to a dirty brown map and see not three but seven flashing icons, representing the seven trapped maidens. The epic music is melodically twisted as a new excitement overcomes you.

Welcome to the Dark World.
author: Chris W

author: lionheart1827

text: @Jlinkburritomaster It only followed the basic Zelda style gameplay, which by then was another mainstay. OoT was also extremely short and didn't take as much of an advantage over the N64's abilities as it could have. Now, OoT's plot was great and the characters themselves were far more in-depth than anything made previously for Zelda, but that can't make up for mediocre gameplay. So yes, ALttP > OoT, but not because "they're the same game only different". Really, OoT is just more popular.
author: KazukiriMishamiota

text: @Jlinkburritomaster It's not that I don't agree with you, but... I think you're honestly mistaken in saying that OoT is ALttP turned 3D with plot-change due to them sharing a few mainstay features like Cuccos, the Lost Woods, the Master Sword, etc. There is no doubt that ALttP is the superior game - the plot's great, the gameplay is extraordinary, and the music is epic -  but it and OoT are very different. OoT's gameplay was far less fun and bore practically no resemblance to ALttP's.
author: KazukiriMishamiota

author: VanHelsing248

text:
You got a point there but one significant detail is missing that would make Zelda a RPG: Link doesn't get stronger by fighting enemies. It is true that he gets better while the game progresses, but this happens in other games that are clearly no RPGs as well, like when you get a stronger weapon in a shooter.

This basically makes Zelda into an Action-Adventure with RPG-Elements rather than a full RPG. Just my opinion.

text: My own definition of an RPG is a game which I play to assume the role of a fictional character. Many games - including the Zelda - I personally play to kill, solve, build, etc. As agglefragglecalp said, almost all games would be RPGs if the definition was just the raw name.

author: Ollav2k

text:
Yes, it is an RPG.

A role-playing game (RPG; often roleplaying game) is a game in which the participants assume the roles of fictional characters. Participants determine the actions of their characters based on their characterization,and the actions succeed or fail according to a formal system of rules and guidelines. Within the rules, players have the freedom to improvise; their choices shape the direction and outcome of the game

However, it is an action/RPG, but still an RPG.

text:
This song always gives me the feeling of actually being in the game.

Sounds bold and heroic. Link will press onward through the dark veils of the once Golden Land at any cost to rescue the Golden Power from the demon thief Ganon. The main part of the song represents the corruption of the land and the percussion in the background demonstrates the Hero's bold efforts.

author: Infornographer

text:
Think harder...

Ever since ALttP came out, think of the other Zelda games. right now, I'm thinking of a Zelda game where you collect 3 precious items, get the Master Sword, defeat more dungeons, fight Ganon. There are 4 or 5 Zelda games I could be talking about...

Also, the "Dark World" from ALttP could also represent Older Link's Hyrule in OoT, Termina of MM, The Great Sea of tWW, Subrosia of OoS, and as you mentioned and more obviously, the Twilight Realm of TP.
